DESCRIPTION: The connection between employee well-being and benefits to organizations are well established. Employees with lower stress levels are more engaged, productive, and have lower absenteeism than those with higher stress levels. Furthermore, employee well-being is associated with greater employee performance, and research suggests that a leader's positive mood can even support better team functioning.

Employee Burnout- the 5 main causes

Workplace stress leads to less productive employees

Sleep deprivation affects performance

DESCRIPTION: Research suggests that using effective influence strategies results in higher levels of effectiveness at work and commitment from others. In contrast, certain influence tactics such as appealing to one's positional authority can actually backfire and leave others less motivated to follow through with your request. As a result, effective influence is a key skill not just for individuals, but also for building a culture of trust and commitment.

DESCRIPTION:
Employees produce more, work more, stay at companies longer and will sacrifice higher pay if they find meaning in their work - based on data from 2,285 American professionals across 26 industries and a range of company sizes, occupations and demographics (The Meaning and Purpose at Work study)

  • Nine of 10 workers will trade money for meaning. On average, they’d sacrifice 23 percent of future earnings —an average of $21,000 a year—for work that is always meaningful.
  • Meaningful work retains, inspires talent. Employees who find their work highly meaningful stay at jobs for an average of 7.4 months longer than employees who find work lacking meaning. When managers find jobs highly meaningful, turnover rates plummet to 1.5 percent, less than half the national average
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
BetterUp: Workers value meaning at work

BetterUp X HBR: America's Loneliest Workers, According to Research

DESCRIPTION: Growth mindset is the belief that talent is developable rather than fixed. Having a growth mindset has many benefits to individuals and organization. It has been found to increase job satisfaction, improve job performance, increase the effectiveness of job training, help employees be more open to feedback, and persist in the face of setbacks.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
Goal Orientation and goal content as predicators of performance

What Having a Growth Mindset Actually Means

DESCRIPTION: Research estimates that 25% of people experience discomfort speaking in front of groups. However, effective presentation skills are extremely valuable for sharing information, getting buy-in, and inspiring others. Therefore learning to tell a compelling story, understand your audience, and manage the emotions that come along with speaking in front of groups can have a significant positive impact on the organization as a whole.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
Why are we scared of public speaking?

Storytelling That Moves People

DESCRIPTION: According to research, organizations who provide opportunities for career development are six times more likely to engage their talent than those who do not. This is particularly true for Millennial employees who place grater value on growth and development. As a result, helping employees develop their long-term career plan can keep them engaged by envisioning a future career path that they can work to achieve.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
Only 1 in 10 Employees Define Success at Work as High Performance 

Millennials Want Jobs to Be Development Opportunities

DESCRIPTION: In the modern workplace, it can be difficult to engage in deep work due to constant interruptions from modern technology, meetings, and multiple priorities competing for our attention. However, the improved focus has been associated with job performance, satisfaction, and commitment, as well as lower turnover and absenteeism. As a result, developing employees' ability to focus can have significant benefits to organizations.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
Stop Letting Push Notifications Ruin Your Productivity

Relationships of personality and job characteristics with organization-based self-esteem

DESCRIPTION: Higher levels of emotional intelligence has been linked to job performance as well as leader effectiveness. Specifically, the ability to perceive and regulate the emotions of ourselves and others is a key skill for building trusting relationships and operating effectively within organizations. Increased empathy also improves our ability to work across cultures, which can be an important skill for improving inclusiveness in the workplace.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
The Relationship between Emotional Intelligence and Job Performance

Empathy Is Still Lacking in The Leaders Who Need It The Most

DESCRIPTION: Self-awareness has been cited as the most important capability for leaders to develop. A study also found that self-awareness impacts companies’ bottom line. In a study of the stock performance of 486 publicly traded companies, Korn/Ferry International found that companies with strong financial performance tend to have employees with higher levels of self-awareness than poorly performing companies.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
HBR: How leaders become self-aware

DESCRIPTION: Change can be difficult to navigate and has been associated with with higher levels of stress and burnout. Our data shows that employees who have access to BetterUp are better able to cope with stress, achieving 14% lower stress and 12% decreases in burnout. As a result, BetterUp can be a powerful tool for helping employees cope effectively with change and avoid the negative repercussions that can affect job performance.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:

DESCRIPTION: Loneliness has been called a modern epidemic. However, high-quality relationships are associated with job performance, creativity, satisfaction, commitment, and lower turnover. As a result, helping employees develop and navigate their personal relationships can support organizational outcomes and build social capital within the organization.

DESCRIPTION: BetterUp's research suggests that employees with stronger relationships at work have higher job satisfaction, more promotions, lower turnover, and better business outcomes. Furthermore, an investigation at Google about what makes for an effective team found that the proper mix of backgrounds and personalities did not appear to predict high performance, but rather the most important factor was the climate of trust on the team, or what researchers refer to as psychological safety.

DESCRIPTION: Managing conflict and having difficult conversations is a challenge everyone experiences at some point in their career. However, research suggests that higher levels of emotional intelligence is associated with better relationships and fewer negative interactions. By developing the right emotional skills like self-awareness, empathy, and self-regulation, these conversations can lead to significant growth and stronger relationships.

DESCRIPTION: Executive presence is considered a "make-or-break" quality for advancing to a senior leadership role, however, it is often hard to describe and difficult to develop. Presence starts with self-confidence, and employees who work with BetterUp report 6% higher self-confidence after working with BetterUp than when they started. In addition, making small changes in our non-verbal behaviors can make a significant impact on how others perceive our abilities.

DESCRIPTION: When employees are confident they exert more effort, are more likely to persist through challenges, and strive for higher levels of achievement. As a result, confidence has been directly correlated with job performance. In addition, confidence levels have been linked to an individual's openness to change. As a result, building employees' confidence can lead to a higher performing and agile employee population.
EXTERNAL_RESOURCES:
Self-Efficacy: Implications for Organizational Behavior and Human Resource Management

DESCRIPTION: Research suggests that receiving consistent high-quality feedback is associated with 27% higher performance. However, we often have strong biases that make it difficult to evaluate others objectively, and if provided improperly, feedback can actually negatively impact performance. As a result, helping employees to give effective feedback has enormous potential to impact the broader productivity of an organization.

DESCRIPTION: Enhancing productivity is about increasing output with the same level of resources, however research suggests that putting more on an employee's plate can actually harm performance because human beings are terrible multitaskers. As a result, to increase productivity employees need to develop new skills, which also supports their development and satisfaction at work. When employees increase their productivity it allows organizations to achieve greater results without increasing headcount.
